awd_titl_txt: Effects of Surface-Adsorbed Biomolecules and Geomolecules on the Photoreactivity of Metal Oxide Nanomaterials
awd_abstract_narration:
Recently, new nanomaterials that can degrade organic pollutants under sunlight irradiation (photoreaction or photocatalysis) have been identified and developed. This unique photoreactivity makes them attractive for applications in diverse water treatment technologies.  On the other hand, this property can also correlate to the toxicological hazard of nanomaterials in natural environments.  Predicting nanomaterial photoreactivity is challenging in aqueous environments since the surface of the nanomaterial can become coated with a complex mixture of biomolecules and natural organic matter.  The interactions of these complex surface coatings with the irradiated nanomaterial and the resulting impact on the effective photoreactivity of the nanomaterial are not yet well understood.  A further challenge is to generalize the coating effects across a variety of photocatalytic nanomaterials currently being investigated. Examples of photocatalytic nanomaterials include titanium dioxide, which is activated by ultraviolet light, and novel visible light active nanomaterials, such as molybdenum oxide that could show improved viability for water treatment applications.  This research will investigate the mechanisms underlying the formation of complex surface coatings and their effects on the photoreactivity of various metal oxide nanomaterials. The fundamental knowledge and models developed in this research will facilitate the development of effective and safe photocatalytic nanomaterials for environmental applications and alleviate the burden on industry and regulatory agencies for large-scale testing of nanomaterials. The results of this research will be disseminated to the public through a joint program between the University of Houston and local museums called "Unveiling the World of Nanomaterials." This program aims to expose and recruit K-12 students, particularly from underrepresented groups, to careers in science and engineering. This research will also be incorporated into hands-on modules for high school teachers to disseminate knowledge to high school students in the Houston area, demonstrate impacts of nanotechnology on society, and recruit teachers to conduct research in the field of nanotechnology. Finally, the results will be incorporated into undergraduate and graduate environmental engineering courses on water quality and environmental modeling at the University of Houston. 

The overarching goal of this research is to develop a model that is capable of predicting the effects of surface coatings on photoreactivity across a variety of photocatalytic, metal oxide nanomaterials, including titanium dioxide and molybdenum oxide. The effect of the coating is hypothesized to be predictable from the composition of the surface coating, which will dictate the type and extent of coating interactions with the photoreactive nanomaterials. Novel approaches and analytical tools will be incorporated in this research to enable a mechanistic understanding of the coating effects, including (1) direct characterization and control of surface coating formation onto photocatalytic nanomaterials from heterogeneous mixtures of biomolecules and natural organic matter, (2) validation and refinement of complementary biological and chemical assays to quantify photoreactivity, and (3) application of in situ spectroscopic methods to identify and monitor the reactions of specific coating components on the nanomaterial surface.  The detailed surface chemistry and reactivity data obtained in this research will ultimately be used to develop quantitative models expressing the fundamental mechanisms by which organic surface coatings modify the effective photoreactivity of nanomaterials.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Photocatalytic nanoparticles are particles with dimensions in the 1 to 100 nm size range that are activated by light to produce reactive species at the particle surface. These reactive properties can be utilized to degrade pollutants in water treatment applications. Examples of photocatalytic nanomaterials include titanium dioxide (TiO2), which is activated by ultraviolet light, and molybdenum trioxide (MoO3), which is activated by lower energy visible light. However, the utility of these nanomaterials can be challenging in practical applications because the nanoparticles may undergo transformations, such as dissolution. Furthermore, the surface of the nanoparticles can become coated or fouled by other constituents in the water, such as natural organic matter and biological molecules, that negatively impact the reaction efficiency for pollutant degradation. These particle transformation processes are not yet well understood, as they require a thorough understanding of the material properties, together with theoretical models that can be generalized to predict the surface fouling process and effects across various water treatment scenarios.

This project achieved the overarching goal of advancing the scientific basis for applications of photocatalytic nanomaterials in water treatment. The research was driven by the need for advanced treatment processes capable of eliminating hazardous pollutants in water, as well as scientific questions regarding the mechanisms controlling nanoparticle transformations and their subsequent photoreactivity in water treatment applications. Three specific objectives were completed to accomplish this goal: (1) synthesis and evaluation of visible light active MoO3 nanomaterials for contaminant removal, (2) investigation of surface fouling of the MoO3 and TiO2 nanoparticles by natural organic matter, proteins, and polysaccharides, and (3) identification of the key reactive species involved in contaminant degradation for the MoO3 and TiO2 nanoparticles, ultimately resulting in the development of a model to predict reactivity in the presence of multiple foulants. The research integrated laboratory experiments and modeling to characterize the nanomaterials and predict their behaviors in water treatment applications. Several key research outcomes were achieved. First, novel MoO3 nanomaterials were developed that were hybridized with magnetic nanoparticles and conductive polymers to improve the stability and reusability of the nanoparticles, as well as enhance their reactivity for contaminant removal. In addition, advanced analytical methods were applied to monitor the surface chemistry of the nanoparticles in the presence of foulant mixtures (i.e., natural organic matter and proteins), leading to the development of a new model to predict the foulant layer composition based on the rates of adsorption. The predominant reactive species generated by the MoO3 and TiO2 nanoparticles were identified in contaminant degradation experiments, along with the impact of the surface foulants on these reactive species. Finally, a fundamental surface reactivity model was developed that incorporates the new models for surface fouling to successfully predict contaminant degradation rates in complex water chemistries.

This research contributes intellectual merit in providing critical knowledge on the functional relationships between the properties of photocatalytic nanomaterials (including nanoparticle structure and surface chemistry) and their reactivity. The theoretical models developed in this research are generally applicable in the broader fields of environmental science and technology and materials science to explain surface adsorption and reaction processes. Overall, this knowledge will facilitate the development of more effective nanomaterials for environmental applications. The results of this research have also produced broader impacts through the development and dissemination of educational products. Specifically, hands-on experiments were developed to demonstrate the materials synthesis and water purification applications. These activities were regularly presented in STEM and Earth Day events at the Children?s Museum of Houston to introduce elementary school students and the public to nanotechnology for environmental applications, as well as high school outreach events at the University of Houston for student recruitment into civil and environmental engineering disciplines. The research findings were successfully integrated into environmental engineering courses at the University of Houston, resulting in the recruitment and participation of several undergraduate and graduate researchers, primarily from underrepresented groups, in conducting the research. The project also contributed to the training of three doctoral students and one postdoctoral fellow. All students engaged in the project gained skills and knowledge that have translated to careers in engineering and environmental disciplines. Finally, the new knowledge has been disseminated to the broader scientific community through publications and national conference presentations.


Last Modified: 10/27/2022
Modified by: Stacey M Louie
